column1: #Text=NbAs single crystals were synthesized by chemical vapor transport using iodine as the transport agent.
#Text=We first obtained a polycrystalline precursor, then grew single crystals from it.
#Text=Precursor polycrystalline samples were prepared from a mixture of high-purity (>99.99%) Nb and As elements.
#Text=The mixture was sealed under high vacuum in a quartz tube, which was sealed in another evacuated tube for extra protection.
#Text=First, the vessel was heated to 600 °C at a rate of 50 °C/h.
#Text=After 10 h’ soaking, it was slowly heated to 1050 °C at a rate of 30 °C/h and then kept at this temperature for 24 h.
#Text=Finally the vessel was cooled to room temperature.
#Text=From the resulting polycrystalline precursor, single crystals were grown using chemical vapor transport in a two-zone furnace.
#Text=The polycrystalline NbAs powder and 0.46 mg/cm3 of iodine were loaded into a 24-mm-diameter quartz tube and sealed under vacuum.
#Text=The charged part of the tube was kept at 1150 °C and the other end was kept at 1000 °C for three weeks.
#Text=The resulting crystals with shiny mirror-like surfaces can be as large as 0.5–1.0 mm in size, suitable for standard high-resolution ARPES measurements.
